question_text: How do you handle test data using DataProviders in TestNG?
option_d: @DataProvider supplies test data to @Test methods. Returns Object[][] array. Can be used for parameterized testing. Example: @DataProvider(name='testData') public Object[][] getData() { return new Object[][] {{'user1','pass1'}, {'user2','pass2'}}; }

question_text: What are different strategies for cross-browser testing?
option_d: Strategies: Use TestNG parameters for different browsers, Selenium Grid for parallel execution, BrowserStack/SauceLabs for cloud testing, Validate CSS/JavaScript compatibility, Test responsive design, Use WebDriverManager for driver management.

question_text: How do you configure Selenium Grid for parallel execution?
option_d: Setup: Start Hub: java -jar selenium-server-standalone.jar -role hub; Start Nodes: java -jar selenium-server-standalone.jar -role node -hub http://hub:4444; In tests, use RemoteWebDriver with Hub URL. Configure TestNG for parallel execution.

question_text: What is the difference between performance testing and load testing?
option_d: Performance Testing: Measures system responsiveness, speed under normal load. Load Testing: Tests system behavior under expected/user load. Stress Testing: Tests beyond normal capacity. Selenium is for functional testing, not load testing (use JMeter).

question_text: How do you integrate Selenium with Appium for mobile testing?
option_d: Appium uses WebDriver protocol. Setup similar to Selenium: Set DesiredCapabilities for device, app, platform. Use AppiumDriver instead of WebDriver. Same Page Object Model can be reused for web and mobile if responsive design.

question_text: How do you verify database data in Selenium tests?
option_d: Use JDBC to connect to database in tests: Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(url, user, password); Execute queries: Statement stmt = conn.createStatement(); ResultSet rs = stmt.executeQuery('SELECT * FROM users'); Assert results match UI data.

question_text: How do you integrate API testing with Selenium tests?
option_d: Use libraries like RestAssured or HttpClient for API calls within Selenium tests. Example: Validate API response before UI test, Set up test data via API, Clean up via API after test. Hybrid approach for comprehensive testing.

question_text: What is Cucumber BDD and how to integrate with Selenium?
option_d: Cucumber executes plain text specifications as automated tests. Features: Feature files (Gherkin syntax), Step Definitions (Java methods), Runner classes. Integrate with Selenium in step definitions for UI automation.

question_text: How do you implement logging in Selenium framework?
option_d: Use Log4j or SLF4J: Configure log4j.properties/xml, Create Logger instance: private static final Logger log = LogManager.getLogger(TestClass.class); Log messages: log.info('Test started'), log.error('Test failed', e). Capture screenshots on failure.

question_text: How do you set up Continuous Integration with Selenium?
option_d: Steps: Create Maven/Gradle project, Write tests, Add testng.xml, Configure Jenkins job: Source Code Management (Git), Build triggers, Post-build actions (publish reports), Add email notifications, Schedule runs, Parallel execution.

question_text: What is the difference between Maven and Gradle for Selenium?
option_d: Maven: XML configuration (pom.xml), predefined lifecycle, extensive plugin ecosystem. Gradle: Groovy/Kotlin DSL, faster builds, incremental compilation, flexible. Both manage dependencies, but Gradle offers more flexibility and performance.

question_text: How do you handle test execution retry in TestNG?
option_d: Implement IRetryAnalyzer interface: public boolean retry(ITestResult result) { if (retryCount < maxRetry) { retryCount++; return true; } return false; } Use @Test(retryAnalyzer = RetryAnalyzer.class).

question_text: What is the difference between soft assert and hard assert?
option_d: Hard assert (Assert.assertEquals): Stops test on failure. Soft assert (SoftAssert softAssert = new SoftAssert()): Collects failures, continues test execution, reports all at end with softAssert.assertAll(). Use soft asserts for non-critical validations.

question_text: How do you handle test dependencies in TestNG?
option_d: Use dependsOnMethods or dependsOnGroups in @Test: @Test(dependsOnMethods = {'loginTest'}) or @Test(dependsOnGroups = {'init'}). Tests execute in dependency order. Use alwaysRun=true to run despite dependencies.

question_text: What is the purpose of @Parameters annotation in TestNG?
option_d: @Parameters passes values from testng.xml to test methods. Example: @Test @Parameters({'browser','url'}) public void test(String browser, String url). Define parameters in testng.xml: <parameter name='browser' value='chrome'/>.

question_text: How do you implement data-driven testing with Excel?
option_d: Use Apache POI library: Workbook workbook = WorkbookFactory.create(file); Sheet sheet = workbook.getSheet(sheetName); Row row = sheet.getRow(rowNum); Cell cell = row.getCell(colNum); Read data into Object[][] for DataProvider.

question_text: What is the difference between @FindBy and driver.findElement()?
option_d: @FindBy is annotation used with PageFactory for lazy initialization. driver.findElement() is direct method call. @FindBy provides cleaner code in Page Objects, automatic element initialization. driver.findElement() gives more control, immediate finding.

question_text: How do you handle test execution order in TestNG?
option_d: Methods: Use priority attribute: @Test(priority=1); Use dependsOnMethods; Use testng.xml <test> order; Use @BeforeMethod/@AfterMethod for setup/teardown. Default: alphabetical order of method names if no priority specified.

question_text: What is the purpose of testng.xml file?
option_d: testng.xml configures TestNG execution: Define test suites, test classes, methods, parameters, groups, parallel execution, listeners, dependencies. Centralized configuration for running tests with different configurations.

question_text: How do you implement custom listeners in TestNG?
option_d: Implement ITestListener interface: onTestStart, onTestSuccess, onTestFailure, onTestSkipped methods. Register in testng.xml: <listeners><listener class-name='com.example.CustomListener'/></listeners> or @Listeners annotation.

question_text: What is the difference between @BeforeSuite and @BeforeTest?
option_d: @BeforeSuite: Runs once before all tests in the suite. @BeforeTest: Runs once before any test method in <test> tag. @BeforeSuite is higher level (suite level), @BeforeTest is test tag level in testng.xml hierarchy.

question_text: How do you handle parallel test execution in TestNG?
option_d: In testng.xml: <suite name='Suite' parallel='tests' thread-count='5'>. Levels: tests, classes, methods, instances. Combine with Selenium Grid for cross-browser parallel execution. Use thread-safe WebDriver instances.

question_text: What is the purpose of @Factory annotation in TestNG?
option_d: @Factory creates instances of test classes dynamically. Useful for parameterized tests where each parameter needs separate test instance. Returns Object[] of test class instances. Different from @DataProvider which runs same test multiple times.

question_text: How do you handle test grouping in TestNG?
option_d: Use groups attribute: @Test(groups={'smoke','regression'}). In testng.xml: <groups><run><include name='smoke'/></run></groups>. Can exclude groups: <exclude name='slow'/>. Useful for categorizing tests (smoke, regression, etc.).

question_text: What is the difference between JUnit and TestNG?
option_d: JUnit: Simple, community standard, integrated with IDEs. TestNG: More features - parameterized tests, dependencies, grouping, parallel execution, annotations, flexible configuration (XML). TestNG preferred for Selenium due to richer features.

question_text: How do you implement keyword-driven testing?
option_d: Approach: Create Excel/CSV with keywords (actions) and parameters; Build keyword library mapping keywords to methods; Engine reads spreadsheet and executes corresponding methods. Separates test design from automation implementation.

question_text: What is the purpose of WebDriver Event Listeners?
option_d: AbstractWebDriverEventListener: Track WebDriver events (before/after clicks, navigation, etc.). Useful for logging, taking screenshots on failure, performance measurement. Implement and register: driver.register(new EventListener());

question_text: How do you handle browser cookies for authentication?
option_d: Store cookies after login: Set<Cookie> cookies = driver.manage().getCookies(); Save to file. In new session: driver.get(url); for(Cookie cookie : cookies) { driver.manage().addCookie(cookie); } driver.navigate().refresh(); Faster than UI login.

question_text: What is the difference between getWindowHandles() and getWindowHandle()?
option_d: getWindowHandle(): Returns current window handle (String). getWindowHandles(): Returns Set<String> of all window handles. Use getWindowHandle() to get current, getWindowHandles() to switch between windows or count open windows.

question_text: How do you handle browser proxy settings in Selenium?
option_d: Use Proxy class: Proxy proxy = new Proxy(); proxy.setHttpProxy('host:port'); DesiredCapabilities capabilities = new DesiredCapabilities(); capabilities.setCapability(CapabilityType.PROXY, proxy); WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver(capabilities);

question_text: What is the purpose of Chrome DevTools Protocol in Selenium 4?
option_d: CDP allows direct communication with Chrome browser. Features: Network throttling, geolocation override, performance metrics, console logs, service workers. Usage: driver.executeCdpCommand('command', parameters); Selenium 4 has built-in CDP support.

question_text: How do you handle browser permissions (camera, microphone) in Selenium?
option_d: ChromeOptions: options.addArguments('--use-fake-ui-for-media-stream'); options.addArguments('--use-fake-device-for-media-stream'); For Firefox: profile.setPreference('media.navigator.permission.disabled', true); Disables permission prompts for media devices.

question_text: What is the difference between switchTo().defaultContent() and switchTo().parentFrame()?
option_d: switchTo().defaultContent(): Returns to main page (top-level document). switchTo().parentFrame(): Moves to parent frame of current frame. Use defaultContent() to exit all frames, parentFrame() to move one level up in nested frames.

question_text: How do you handle browser storage (localStorage, sessionStorage)?
option_d: Use JavaScriptExecutor: ((JavascriptExecutor)driver).executeScript('return localStorage.getItem(key)'); To set: executeScript('localStorage.setItem(key, value)'); To clear: executeScript('localStorage.clear()'); Same for sessionStorage.

question_text: What is the difference between driver.manage().window().maximize() and fullscreen()?
option_d: maximize(): Maximizes browser window within screen (shows OS taskbar). fullscreen(): Full screen mode (hides OS taskbar, browser controls). fullscreen() is more like F11 fullscreen. maximize() is more commonly used for testing.

question_text: How do you handle browser console errors in tests?
option_d: Use LogEntries: LogEntries logEntries = driver.manage().logs().get(LogType.BROWSER); Check for SEVERE level messages. Assert no errors: Assert.assertEquals(0, logEntries.getAll().stream().filter(e -> e.getLevel() == Level.SEVERE).count());

question_text: What is the purpose of FluentWait in Selenium?
option_d: FluentWait allows customizing wait conditions with polling frequency and ignoring exceptions. Example: Wait<WebDriver> wait = new FluentWait<>(driver).withTimeout(Duration.ofSeconds(30)).pollingEvery(Duration.ofSeconds(5)).ignoring(NoSuchElementException.class);

question_text: How do you handle browser back/forward navigation?
option_d: driver.navigate().back(); // Go back to previous page; driver.navigate().forward(); // Go forward; driver.navigate().refresh(); // Refresh current page; Can also use JavaScript: ((JavascriptExecutor)driver).executeScript('window.history.go(-1)');

question_text: What is the difference between Actions and Action interfaces?
option_d: Actions class: Builder pattern to create complex user interactions. Action interface: Represents single user interaction. Pattern: Actions actions = new Actions(driver); Action action = actions.moveToElement(element).click().build(); action.perform();

question_text: How do you handle browser startup arguments in Chrome?
option_d: ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions(); options.addArguments('--start-maximized'); options.addArguments('--incognito'); options.addArguments('--disable-notifications'); options.addArguments('--headless'); options.addArguments('user-agent=custom-agent');

question_text: What is the difference between driver.getCurrentUrl() and driver.getTitle()?
option_d: getCurrentUrl(): Returns current page URL as String. getTitle(): Returns current page title as String. Both used for navigation verification. Example: Assert.assertEquals('Expected Title', driver.getTitle()); Assert.assertTrue(driver.getCurrentUrl().contains('login'));

question_text: How do you handle browser session management?
option_d: Store session ID: String sessionId = ((RemoteWebDriver)driver).getSessionId().toString(); Reuse sessions: Store cookies as shown earlier; Use same WebDriver instance for related tests; Implement WebDriver pooling for performance; Properly quit() to end sessions.

question_text: What is the purpose of WebDriverWait with ExpectedConditions?
option_d: WebDriverWait waits for specific condition with timeout. Example: WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, Duration.ofSeconds(10)); wait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(locator)); Conditions: visibilityOf, presenceOfElementLocated, alertIsPresent, etc.

question_text: How do you handle browser download directory?
option_d: ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions(); Map<String, Object> prefs = new HashMap<>(); prefs.put('download.default_directory', '/path/to/downloads'); options.setExperimentalOption('prefs', prefs); Ensure directory exists and has write permissions.

question_text: What is the difference between findElements() and findElement() with timeout?
option_d: findElements() returns empty list if no elements found (no exception). findElement() throws NoSuchElementException immediately if element not found. With implicit wait, findElement() waits up to timeout before throwing exception. findElements() also respects implicit wait.

question_text: How do you handle browser window positioning?
option_d: Set window position: driver.manage().window().setPosition(new Point(x, y)); Get position: Point position = driver.manage().window().getPosition(); Set size: driver.manage().window().setSize(new Dimension(width, height)); Useful for multi-monitor testing.

question_text: What is the purpose of driver.switchTo().activeElement()?
option_d: Returns the element that currently has focus. Useful for forms where focus changes dynamically. Example: WebElement activeElement = driver.switchTo().activeElement(); activeElement.sendKeys('text'); Can be used after tab navigation or modal dialogs.

question_text: How do you handle browser font settings in Selenium?
option_d: Limited control via browser options. Can set minimum font size: ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions(); options.addArguments('--force-device-scale-factor=1'); options.addArguments('--high-dpi-support=1'); For font testing, use visual validation tools (Applitools, Percy).

question_text: What is the difference between driver.getPageSource() and driver.findElement()?
option_d: getPageSource(): Returns entire page HTML as String. findElement(): Finds specific element on page. getPageSource() useful for: verifying certain text exists, debugging, checking meta tags. findElement() for interacting with specific elements.

question_text: How do you handle browser safe browsing warnings?
option_d: For Chrome: options.addArguments('--disable-features=SafeBrowsing'); options.addArguments('--safebrowsing-disable-download-protection'); For testing environments, disable safe browsing to avoid warnings interfering with tests.

question_text: What is the purpose of driver.manage().timeouts().pageLoadTimeout()?
option_d: Sets maximum time to wait for page to load completely. Example: driver.manage().timeouts().pageLoadTimeout(Duration.ofSeconds(30)); If page takes longer, throws TimeoutException. Useful for slow networks or heavy pages.

question_text: How do you handle browser print dialogs?
option_d: For Chrome: options.addArguments('--kiosk-printing'); Automatically accepts print dialog. For more control, use AutoIT or Robot class to handle native dialogs. Alternative: Use JavaScript window.print() and handle with DevTools.

question_text: What is the difference between driver.quit() and System.exit()?
option_d: driver.quit(): Properly closes WebDriver session, closes browser, releases resources. System.exit(0): Terminates JVM immediately. Use driver.quit() in @AfterMethod/@AfterTest. Never use System.exit() in tests as it stops entire test execution.

question_text: How do you handle browser autofill settings?
option_d: Disable autofill for consistent tests: ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions(); options.addArguments('--disable-autofill'); For testing autofill functionality, use saved profiles with pre-filled data.

question_text: What is the purpose of driver.manage().timeouts().scriptTimeout()?
option_d: Sets maximum time for asynchronous script execution. Example: driver.manage().timeouts().scriptTimeout(Duration.ofSeconds(30)); For executeAsyncScript() calls. If script takes longer, throws TimeoutException.

question_text: How do you handle browser hardware acceleration?
option_d: Disable for consistent rendering: ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions(); options.addArguments('--disable-gpu'); options.addArguments('--disable-software-rasterizer'); Useful for headless testing or virtual machines where GPU may not be available.

question_text: What is the difference between driver.get() and JavaScript navigation?
option_d: driver.get(url): Standard navigation, waits for page load. JavaScript navigation: ((JavascriptExecutor)driver).executeScript('window.location.href = \url\"'); May not wait for page load. Use driver.get() for reliable navigation with timeout control."

question_text: How do you handle browser content settings (popups, images)?
option_d: ChromeOptions: options.addArguments('--blink-settings=imagesEnabled=false'); // Disable images; options.addArguments('--disable-popup-blocking'); For more control: Use DevTools Protocol to modify content settings.

question_text: What is the purpose of driver.manage().window().getSize()?
option_d: Returns current browser window size as Dimension object. Example: Dimension size = driver.manage().window().getSize(); int width = size.getWidth(); int height = size.getHeight(); Useful for responsive testing, verifying window dimensions.
